text:
ROBIN ELY: So welcome back
to the many of you who

have been coming all along or
have made it to many of these,

and welcome to those of you
who are new to the conference.

We're really excited
about what we

have planned for the
next day and a half,

and we're extremely
excited about our topic.

We had a really great time over
the last week or so putting

together the images that
you have been seeing
in the background all morning.

And that is the
work, by the way,
of our fantastic planning team.

So all of you probably
have had some interaction
with Ethi Al-Mahdi.
Where's Ethi?

She's outside
working, of course.
Anyway, there she is.
Thank you, Ethi.
So Liz Johnson, where's Liz?
There.

This is Liz's
fourth time with us

on the planning
team and her last,

since she is going to be
going off to graduate school

somewhere, we hope here,
but we don't know yet.
That's going to be her choice.

Lauren Moran, she
was also outside,

and of course, Colleen
Ammerman, who's

been with us from
the very beginning.

So let's just give
a round of applause.

They are really the
people who really make
this happen and pull it off.

OK, so let me just give you a
little bit of background here.

I want to reiterate a
little bit about what

we said in our invitation
to you and give you

a bit of background on
our theme, the courage

of our convictions, which as
we said in the invitation,

aims to unpack the beliefs and
actions that define, unite,

and separate us so that we
might more effectively engage

in the project of advancing
structural equality
in the workplace and beyond.

So let me just say a little
bit about the origins
of this year's theme.

I think it's obvious that
it's super pertinent to what's

happening on the political
scene, even in the US
and around the world.

But I'd like to just say a
little bit about specifically
how it evolved.

So it was initially inspired
by the topic of actually

our second panel today, which
is the panel after lunch, which

is Jen Berdhal, Peter Glick,
and Mary Ann Cooper, who are all

here somewhere,
where we're going
to present a case of a kind.

It's a dilemma that we
faced late last summer

when we were informed
of allegations

that a colleague had sexually
harassed a doctoral student.

So we're going to tell
you all about that later.

But the piece
that's relevant here

really centers on
the disagreements

that we had among us
about what we should do,

if anything, what
action might we

take in relation
to this colleague.

And so here we
were, all feminists,

we've all known each other
for a pretty long time.

I think we all think very
highly of each other, very
much respect each other.

And yet, we were
having a difficult time

because we had different
points of view about that.

And so we decided,
given our differences,

that what we'd like to do is
to bring that dilemma, which

we thought was
probably experienced

in many different ways
by many of the people who

will be in this room, we
decided to bring that dilemma
into a public forum.

And I think it was Jen's idea to
bring it into this conference.

So we thought that was a great
idea, and I ran it by my team.
I thought that was a good idea.

And so I was kind of
mulling that over,

and I woke up one morning
right around then,

and this phrase, the
courage of our convictions,

just kind of entered
into my mind.
And so I googled it, of course.

And what I found, actually
to my surprise, is

there was no one
source for the phrase,

and it had many
different connotations.

And so I talked a little bit
about this in our invitation

to you, but two of them
really captured my attention,

and actually they're
both by Nietzsche.

And the first is along the
lines of what I had in mind

when the phrase first came
to me, and so he wrote,

a very popular error, having the
courage of one's convictions.

Rather, it's a matter of having
the courage for an attack
on one's convictions.

So it is very much the
theme of one's convictions

being something not only to
have the courage to express,

but also to have the courage
to defend against attack.

But then I also found a
quote in which he said,

convictions are more dangerous
foes of truth than lies.

And so taken together,
it seemed to be

urging us to courageously
embrace our convictions

but also remaining open to
learning and open to inquiry

and to doubt when our
convictions are questioned.

So I thought, OK, all
well and good when

it's a group like the four
of us where we are basically

like-minded people and
we respect each other,
but we just happen to disagree.

So what about when the
convictions of others

are hostile to
what we hold dear?
They want to destroy it.
They're vengeful or hateful.

What do we think about
urging those people to have

the courage of
their convictions?

And so that question
really informed

how we thought about
putting the program together
for this year's conference.

And that's the kind of
thinking that informed

this whole collection of images
that we've been showing up

on these screens all morning
where we're juxtaposing,

I'm sure you've noticed, the
likes of high school students

and others protesting
for gun control

or against racism or Christine
Blasey Ford coming forward

in her testimony in the
Kavanaugh hearings and so on.

All these amazing
people, on the one hand,

juxtaposed with
the likes of those

who are participating in
the Unite the Right rally
in Charlottesville.

So that's one of
the images up there.

So people whose
views I think really

couldn't be more hostile,
I think I probably speak

for everybody in this room, to
the values and the convictions
that we hold dear.

So aren't all these images
of people having the courage
of their convictions?

So I thought, well,
there's no question
that they have convictions.
But I thought, is it courage?
Do we share that as well?

And so I thought about
the definition of courage.

And for that, I
turned to Brene Brown.

And what she reminds us is that
the root of the word courage

is cor, the Latin
word for heart.

In one of its earliest
forms, she notes,

the word courage meant
to speak one's mind

by telling all one's heart,
to speak honestly and openly

about who we are and about
our experiences, good and bad.

It's about putting our
vulnerability on the line.

So I thought, wow, are all
these people in these images--
all of them--

are they all speaking
from their heart?

Because I actually see the
Unite the Right rallyists,
and what I see is fear.

And I think it's fear turned
into anger and hatred.

And so then I'm kind of stumped
because don't those emotions

come from the heart, or are they
the consequences of the heart
shutting down?

And so we were talking
about this last night
at the reception.

I'll just kind of leave that
with you to think about.
I don't have an answer to that.
I was stumped.

But anyway, with that as
background, let me pose again

the questions that we're
inviting you to consider
over this next day and a half.

Who gets to speak about
what, to whom, and with what
consequences?

And as we noted
in our invitation,

these questions demand
that we consider

the relationship between
position-taking and identity,

the costs and benefits of
difficult conversations,

and changing notions
about the role

of research and researchers
in contemporary social,
political, and ethical debates.

So it's our hope in this
next day and a half with you,

as we consider these questions
and hear the views and research

of our presenters
and of each other,

that we will foster a
wide-ranging, sophisticated,

and, indeed, courageous
conversation.

So I'm going to turn
it over now to Lakshmi.

She's going to say a few
more words about our theme

and then introduce
our first speaker.
LAKSHMI RAMARAJAN: Welcome.

Thank you all very
much for being here.

So I just wanted to
echo a couple of things

that Robin said and
my idea about what

I hope our conversation
over the next couple of days
would look like.

So the first is a quote
that Larry Bacow actually

said in his inaugural address,
that the search for truth
requires courage.

And if you think about who we
are as scholars in this room--

I always start with identity,
so one common shared identity--

what does it take then
to have the courage

to examine our
convictions, as Robin said,

and then also to
encourage others

to examine their
convictions in order
to come to some kind of truth?

And truth, obviously,
as a very complex

construct where it can
be about shared truth,
personal truth, truth as facts.

All of these are up
for debate, hopefully
over the next couple of days.

The second thought
that came to mind,

as we were thinking about this
whole setup for the conference,

is, of course, the question
of silence and voice.

And another one of my wonderful
mentors and also the person

who was co-leading last year's
conference, David Thomas,

I remember when I
was talking with him,

we were teaching authentic
leadership two years ago.

And he said, well,
the question really

is, are you being silent,
or are you being silenced?

And I do think a question
for us, after identity, I

guess the question is power,
when the powerful remain

silent, is that condoning
what's out in the world,

or is that allowing people
space for doubt and expression
and voice?

And then the third
quote I'll leave you on
is Martin Luther King.

And Colleen reminded
this morning

that today is the day of
the assassination of King.

And he left us with this
very powerful quote,

if we think about the
courage of our convictions

as a way to try to change
the status quo, which

I think we're all engaged
in here, as a community.

We must accept
finite disappointment

but must never
lose infinite hope.

So what does that
mean as we're all

engaged in this collective
discussion for truth,

engaging with doubt, in order
to change the status quo?
How do we keep that going?

And my hope for all of us
as we go through the day

is that we're going to
start with Soraya, who we'll

introduce in a moment, with this
notion of anger and rage, all
of the stuff that's packed in.

But hopefully then
with Robin's panel

and with some of
the conversation

that we're going to have with
the panel after Soraya, talk,

conversation, interpersonal
communication.

And then tomorrow with
Dolly and Kira and also

our evening program
and with Mara,

the idea of ending on voice,
and as King reminds us, hope.

So that's my hope
for all of us today.

And I'm very excited, actually,
to introduce Soraya Chemaly.

She, as you all know, is a
prolific speaker, writer,

advocate for women's
freedom of expression.

And the title of the
book, "Rage Becomes Her,"
I mean, how amazing is that?
How often do we get told that?

And despite living in a
society and a community that's

constantly, in some respects,
belittling rage and belittling

anger and diminishing people
who express that, using anger

as a political tool and a
catalyst for social change,

which, as Robin said, is
the anger coming from fear,

or is the anger coming from that
sense of righteous indignation

and injustice and anger as
this proactive sort of launch
of yourself against the world?

And so I really hope
that we're going

to start off on this note
of parceling all of that

up and throwing the rage
out into the world in order

to create a more
positive difference.
So, Soraya.
